Award.AwardTitle: Exploiting Allenes: Synthesis and Reactivity of Strained Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will continue work to explore the chemistry of allenes, an underutilized functional group in the synthetic chemist's repertoire. Exploiting the reactivity of this moiety led to the discovery of a thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of an allene-yne to afford an alkylidene cyclobutene, the topic of this proposal. Prior to this work, reports of this unsaturated, strained moiety were rare. Ready access to this ring system will facilitate investigations into their chemical reactivity and synthetic utility. Computational and synthetic studies will be undertaken to understand the mechanism of the thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of allene-ynes. The scope of the thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of allene-ynes will be expanded and the synthetic utility of alkylidene cyclobutenes will be explored.

With this award the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program is supporting the research of Professor Kay Brummond of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh. Discovery and synthesis of new arrays of functionality through the development of innovative reactions is the primary aim of Professor Brummond's research program. Realization of the goals of this proposal will provide a more general understanding of the chemistry of strained compounds and an expansion of chemical space, thus enhancing the discovery of new biological probes and pharmaceuticals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes of NSF Grant CHE-0910597, Exploiting Allenes: Synthesis and Reactivity of Strained Compounds.

This work focused on a thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of allene-ynes to afford alkylidene cyclobutenes. Prior to this work, reports of this unsaturated, strained moiety were rare. Ready access to this ring system has facilitated investigations into their chemical reactivity and synthetic utility. In addition, by combining theory and experiment we now understand that the mechanism of this [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction proceeds via a stepwise diradical pathway, information that provides valuable insight, and directs the substrate selection process. In addition, mechanistic studies have led to the discovery of a novel [4 + 2] cycloaddition reaction. Finally, realization of the goals of this proposal provide the scientific community with a more general understanding of the chemistry of strained compounds, and the reactivity of biradicals generated in close proximity to one another, a motif whose existence has rarely been established experimentally. The scope of the thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction was extended to include the synthesis of C3-carbocyclic spirooxindoles, a product that is afforded by a 3,3-sigmatropic rearrangement of a propargylic acetate to give the vinylidene indolin-2-one that then reacts with the tethered alkyne via the thermal, intramolecular [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction. The resulting spirooxindole products are structurally similar to that of welwitindoline A, a potent antifungal agent.

During our investigations to expand the scope of the thermal [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of allene-ynes by intercepting the intermediate biradical with styrene, an intramolecular dehydrogenative dehydro-Diels–Alder (DDDA) reaction affording a cyclopenta[b]naphthalene was observed. While reactions of this type have been reported, mixtures of the naphthalene and dihydronaphthalene products are typically obtained. Synthesis of functionalized naphthalenes remains a synthetic challenge, thus delineating the mechanism, scope and synthetic utility of this thermal reaction is expected to expedite the preparation of biologically relevant naphthalene-containing heterocycles and lactones. These studies are the topic of a new proposal submitted to the NSF in 2013.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2013
Modified by: Kay M Brummond
